question: 2 (c)
sols_html:
Series of this form suggest the ratio test: given powers such as 2k and factorials, we know that in taking the ratio of successive terms, many simplifications are possible.

Let us denote \(a_k = \frac{2^k (k!)^2}{(2k)!}\) so that \(a_{k+1} = \frac{2^{k+1} ((k+1)!)^2}{(2(k+1))!}\).

The ratio test requires us to compute the limit

\[\begin{aligned} L = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} |\frac{a_{k+1}}{a_k} |\end{aligned}\]

Theory tells us that

  • if \(0 \leq L < 1\) then the series converges;

  • if \(\displaystyle L=1\), we cannot conclude anything from the test;

  • if \(\displaystyle L > 1\) then the series diverges.

We need to be careful with the factorials (!). A useful thing to recall is that \((k+1)! = (k+1)k!\).

We will compute:

\[\begin{aligned} L &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \left|\frac{a_{k+1}}{a_k}\right| = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \left|\frac{\frac{2^{k+1}((k+1)!)^2}{(2(k+1))!}}{\frac{2^k (k!)^2}{(2k)!}}\right| \\ &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2^{k+1} ((k+1)!)^2 (2k)!}{2^k (k!)^2 (2(k+1))!} \\ &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2^{k+1-k} \times [(k+1)k!]^2 \times (2k)!}{(k!)^2 \times (2k+2)!} \\ &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2 (k+1)^2 (2k)!}{(2k+2)!} \\ &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2 (k+1)^2 (2k)!}{(2k+2)(2k+1)(2k)!} \\ &= 2 \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(k+1)^2}{(2k+2)(2k+1)} \\ &= 2 \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{k^2 + 2k + 1}{4k^2 + 6k + 2} \\ &= 2 \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{k^2/k^2 + 2k/k^2 + 1/k^2}{4k^2/k^2 + 6k/k^2 + 2/k^2} \\ &= 2(\frac{1}{4}) = \frac12 < 1\end{aligned}\]

As \(0 \leq L < 1\), we determine the series converges.
sols_latex:
Series of this form suggest the ratio test: given powers such as
2\textsuperscript{\emph{k}} and factorials, we know that in taking the
ratio of successive terms, many simplifications are possible.

Let us denote $a_k = \frac{2^k (k!)^2}{(2k)!}$ so that
$a_{k+1} = \frac{2^{k+1} ((k+1)!)^2}{(2(k+1))!}$.

The ratio test requires us to compute the limit

\begin{align*}
L = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} |\frac{a_{k+1}}{a_k} |
\end{align*} Theory tells
us that

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  if $0 \leq L < 1$ then the series converges;
\item
  if $\displaystyle L=1$, we cannot conclude anything from the test;
\item
  if $\displaystyle L > 1$ then the series diverges.
\end{itemize}

We need to be careful with the factorials (!). A useful thing to recall
is that $(k+1)! = (k+1)k!$.

We will compute:

\begin{align*}
L &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \left|\frac{a_{k+1}}{a_k}\right| = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \left|\frac{\frac{2^{k+1}((k+1)!)^2}{(2(k+1))!}}{\frac{2^k (k!)^2}{(2k)!}}\right| \\
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2^{k+1} ((k+1)!)^2 (2k)!}{2^k (k!)^2 (2(k+1))!} \\
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2^{k+1-k} \times [(k+1)k!]^2 \times (2k)!}{(k!)^2 \times (2k+2)!} \\
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2 (k+1)^2 (2k)!}{(2k+2)!} \\
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2 (k+1)^2 (2k)!}{(2k+2)(2k+1)(2k)!} \\
&= 2 \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(k+1)^2}{(2k+2)(2k+1)} \\
&= 2 \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{k^2 + 2k + 1}{4k^2 + 6k + 2} \\
&= 2 \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{k^2/k^2 + 2k/k^2 + 1/k^2}{4k^2/k^2 + 6k/k^2 + 2/k^2} \\
&= 2(\frac{1}{4}) = \frac12 < 1
\end{align*}

As $0 \leq L < 1$, we determine the series converges.

This problem contains three numerical series. For each of them, find out whether it converges or diverges. You should provide appropriate justification in order to receive credit.

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{2^k(k!)^2}{(2k)!}\end{aligned}\]

Recall that \(k! = 1\cdot2\cdot3\cdot \ldots \cdot k\).
